A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6312, Description: Web portals, Level: 4
A34_GDPREvaluated: Art. 5(1)(a), Art. 5(1)(b), Art. 6, Art. 6(4), Art. 9, Art. 10, Art. 17, Art. 13, Art. 21
A35_GDPRViolated: Art. 9, Art. 10, Art. 17, Art. 5(1)(b), Art. 6, Art. 5(1)(a)
A50_CaseSummary: Sweden’s DPA found Google failed to promptly delist certain name-based search results and unlawfully notified webmasters of removals, breaching Articles 9, 10, 17, 5(1)(b), 6, and 5(1)(a). It fined Google SEK 75,000,000 and ordered it to stop webmaster notifications unless the data subject requests them and to correct misleading information in its removal form. The case followed prior injunctions and covered periods from May 25, 2018, with some infringements ongoing.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: The DPA found that Karolinska University Hospital failed to perform needs and risk analyses and granted overly broad access in the TakeCare EHR, violating GDPR Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2), and 32(1)-(2). It imposed a SEK 4,000,000 fine and ordered the hospital to document analyses and restrict user permissions to necessity. Aggravating factors included prior non-compliance with a 2013 order and the large scale and sensitivity of processing affecting about 3 million patients.

A11_DefendantName: The board of Sahlgrenska University Hospital
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
A26_InfringementDuration: Ongoing at the time of the inspection on 23-04-2019
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA found that Sahlgrenska University Hospital failed to perform a proper needs and risk analysis, granted overly broad access to patient data in Melior and NPÖ, and had inadequate logging. It ordered corrective measures and imposed a SEK 3.5 million fine for violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2) and 32. Aggravating factors included prior non-compliance and the hospital’s stated prioritization of availability over confidentiality.

A11_DefendantName: The Health and Medical Care Board at Region Västerbotten
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 86, Description: Human health activities, Level: 2
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA found Region Västerbotten’s Health and Medical Care Board lacked a documented needs and risk analysis and granted overly broad read access in the NCS Cross journal system, exposing health data of about 650k+ patients to unjustified access. It held violations of Art. 5(1)(f), 5(2), and Art. 32(1)-(2), while logging controls met requirements. The DPA ordered implementation of needs/risk analysis with individualized access controls and imposed a SEK 2,500,000 fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 86, Description: Human health activities, Level: 2
A50_CaseSummary: Aleris Sjukvård AB failed to perform needs and risk analyses and to restrict user access in the TakeCare EHR, violating GDPR Art. 5(1)(f), 5(2), and 32(1)-(2). The DPA found logging compliant but ordered documented analyses and individualized need-to-know access. A SEK 15,000,000 fine was imposed given the large scale (about 796,350 patients) and sensitivity of health data.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 86, Description: Human health activities, Level: 2
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA inspected KRY’s telemedicine operations and found insufficient needs and risk analyses and overbroad user access in ProReNata and the National Patient Overview, breaching Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2) and 32(1)-(2). Logs were brought into compliance, but KRY was ordered to further develop risk analyses and reassess permissions by February 2021. No administrative fine was imposed after a proportionality assessment considering remedial steps.

A11_DefendantName: Board of Education in the City of Stockholm
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8412, Description: Regulation of the activities of providing health care, education, cultural services and other social services, excluding social security, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA found Stockholm’s Board of Education lacked adequate technical and organizational security in the School Platform, exposing students’, guardians’ and teachers’ data, including sensitive health data and protected identities. It also failed to conduct required DPIAs despite large-scale, high-risk processing. The DPA imposed a SEK 4,000,000 fine and ordered a DPIA and restriction of authorizations.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA fined Gnosjö Municipality’s Social Affairs Committee 200,000 SEK for unlawful real-time camera surveillance of a resident’s bedroom in an LSS accommodation (March 2019–April 2020). It found no valid Art. 6 legal basis, processed health data without an Art. 9 condition, failed to conduct a DPIA/prior consultation, and breached transparency and signage duties (Art. 13; KBL §15), deeming the surveillance disproportionate. Considering the sensitive context, dependence, and duration, and lack of less-intrusive alternatives, the DPA imposed an effective, proportionate, and dissuasive fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8530, Description: Higher education, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: Umeå University sent a rape case file with sensitive data via unencrypted email over an open network and stored 108 sensitive and confidential preliminary investigation protocols in Box (US), while failing to report or document the incident. The DPA found inadequate security measures (no encryption in email, single-factor authentication and exposure via open network), violations of Art. 5(1)(f), 32(1)(2), and 33(1)(5), and assessed high risk given the nature of the data. A total administrative fine of SEK 550,000 was imposed; transfer via Privacy Shield/BCRs was noted but the breach stemmed from insufficient security.

A11_DefendantName: Health and Medical Board of Region Örebro County
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: A complaint revealed that Region Örebro County’s Health and Medical Board published a complainant’s health data and personal identity number on its public website, lacking a legal basis and breaching purpose limitation, data minimization, and Article 32 due to absent written procedures. The DPA found violations of GDPR Articles 5, 6, 9, and 32 and the national rule on social security numbers, imposed a SEK 120,000 fine, and ordered the Board to implement written instructions and procedures. Factors included sensitivity of health data, the data subject’s dependency position, publication duration, and remedial steps taken after discovery.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6810, Description: Real estate activities with own or leased property, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: The Swedish DPA found Uppsalahem AB’s camera surveillance of a stairwell and parts of apartments unlawful under Article 6(1)(f) and imposed a 300,000 SEK fine. While the landlord’s interest was legitimate and surveillance deemed necessary, tenants’ privacy and fundamental rights in their home environment outweighed it. The decision considered negligence, short duration, and the sensitive context, and imposed only a fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4791, Description: Retail sale via mail order houses or via Internet, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority after complaints from Finland and Denmark, found Lensway Group AB violated Articles 12(6) and 12(2) by unnecessarily requiring ID copies/signatures and insisting on postal submission for erasure requests. IMY accepted the need to verify identity but held less intrusive methods should have been used and that postal-only submission did not facilitate the right. Considering the limited scope (two data subjects in 2020) and remedial changes, IMY issued a reprimand.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that Uppsala Regional Hospital Board failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures for its Outlook email service, breaching Article 32(1) between 25 May 2018 and 29 November 2022. Sensitive patient data, including health information and personal identification numbers, was stored and sent via email without adequate controls, and IMY noted missing proactive detection and technical safeguards. Considering remedial steps and context, IMY issued a reprimand instead of a fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6810, Description: Real estate activities with own or leased property, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that Granit Bostad Beritsholm AB conducted extensive camera surveillance in a Malmö residential property without a valid legal basis except for the garage, and failed to provide required Article 13 information. It imposed a SEK 200,000 administrative fine and ordered the company to cease surveillance in all areas except the garage and to add identity and contact details to signage within four weeks. IMY’s reasoning balanced legitimate interest against privacy, finding necessity but an unfavorable balance in entrances, stairwells and other areas, noted transparency deficiencies, and characterized the conduct as negligent with low overall seriousness.

IMY investigated a cross-border complaint about Aller Media AB’s cookie banner and subsequent processing on recept.se on 21 May 2021. IMY found Aller had not demonstrated a legitimate interest for profiling and precise geodata processing and that objection was only possible after refusing consent, violating Article 6(1)(f) GDPR. Considering the minor nature, prior clean record, and changes made during supervision, IMY issued a reprimand.

IMY upheld a cross-border complaint against ATG, finding that its cookie banner used misleading design and did not make withdrawal of consent as easy as giving it, invalidating consent. IMY concluded violations of GDPR Art. 6 and 7(3), noting transparency concerns in the consent context. Given minor infringements and some remedial steps by ATG, IMY issued a reprimand without a fine.

A11_DefendantName: The Executive Board of the Rescue Service Östra Skaraborg
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8423, Description: Public order and safety activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined the Executive Board of the Rescue Service Östra Skaraborg for camera surveillance in fire station carriage halls that captured staff during changing. IMY upheld Public Task as the legal basis but found violations of fairness and data minimization (Art. 5(1)(a), 5(1)(c)) and inadequate organizational measures under Art. 32 due to lack of instructions and 24/7 monitoring without masking. Surveillance ended on 6 May 2021 and a SEK 350,000 fine was imposed.

A13_InstitutionalIdentity: S.122 - Deposit-taking corporations except the central bank
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined Klarna SEK 7.5 million for inadequate transparency in its privacy information between 17 March and 26 June 2020. Deficiencies covered purposes and legal bases, recipient disclosures, third-country transfers, retention periods, data subject rights, and meaningful information on automated decision-making, violating Arts 5, 12, 13, and 14. IMY considered the scale and seriousness, noted improvements during the investigation, and imposed a proportionate, dissuasive fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 5814, Description: Publishing of journals and periodicals, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY investigated Bonnier Magazines’ webshop registration flow and found it stated consent as the legal basis while processing actually relied on contract or legitimate interest between May 2018 and 4 June 2019. As the company had merged, Expressen Lifestyle AB was held responsible; only 1372 customers were affected and the issue was promptly corrected, so IMY deemed the impact limited. IMY found a violation of Article 13(1)(c) and issued a reprimand.

A26_InfringementDuration: 11 June 2019 to 16 May 2022; and 16 November 2021 to 16 May 2022
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found Spotify’s Article 15 responses unclear and insufficient, including non-individualized information on purposes, data categories, recipients, retention, sources, and third-country safeguards, and provided technical log descriptions only in English. It upheld infringements in two complaints (late response and incomplete or insufficiently understandable copies), while a third complaint was rejected. IMY imposed a SEK 58,000,000 fine, issued a reprimand, and ordered Spotify to fulfill one complainant’s access request within one month.

A11_DefendantName: The Regional Board of the Uppsala Region
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that the Regional Board of the Uppsala Region sent unencrypted Excel files containing sensitive health data and social security numbers via email within the region, breaching Article 32(1) GDPR. Despite transport encryption (TLS 1.2), the file contents were readable after transfer, posing high risk, and the practice violated the region’s own guidelines. Considering the systematic, long-lasting processing affecting up to 500,000 individuals and limited mitigating factors, IMY imposed a SEK 300,000 administrative fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 5813, Description: Publishing of newspapers, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found Bonnier News AB, as joint controller in group-wide databases, lacked a valid legal basis under Art. 6(1) for profiling to deliver customized ads and for sharing contact details for telemarketing when profiles were supplemented. The processing used cookies-derived behavioral data linked with KDB and third-party data, and IMY rejected reliance on legitimate interest, imposing a SEK 13,000,000 fine after cross-border cooperation. Some non-linked KDB marketing was accepted under legitimate interest; mitigation included data minimization and limited retention.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border case, investigated two access requests to Klarna Bank AB under GDPR Articles 12 and 15. It found a breach of Article 12(3) for complaint 1 due to a delay of more than five months without notifying the extension, and issued a reprimand; complaint 2 was handled within 14 days and required no further action. IMY used Chapter VII cooperation with several DPAs and classified the infringement as minor under Recital 148.

IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint, found that MAG Interactive AB violated Article 12(3) by failing to inform the complainant of the outcome of an erasure request from 29 May 2019 until 6 November 2020. The company erased the data within 16 days and was justified in retaining minimal records to evidence compliance, but due to oversight did not notify the complainant. Considering measures taken and planned, IMY closed the case without action.

IMY found Readly AB sent direct marketing emails after the complainant objected, violating Articles 21(3), 12(3), and 6(1) GDPR. It rejected contract as a lawful basis for personalized marketing emails and held that after objection no lawful basis remained. Considering the short duration, non-sensitive data, and negligent nature with remedial action, IMY issued a reprimand.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4791, Description: Retail sale via mail order houses or via Internet, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY investigated seven cross-border complaints that CDON AB made erasure requests unduly burdensome by demanding excessive identity-verification data. It found violations of data minimization and Article 12 obligations, while noting CDON’s later procedure was proportionate. Considering the minor, older infringements and improvements, IMY issued a reprimand without a fine.

IMY investigated Rebtel Networks AB after a cross-border complaint about continued emails and failure to promptly erase data. IMY found violations of Article 17 for delayed erasure and Article 12(3) for providing incorrect information, noting four emails sent shortly after the erasure request. Considering the minor nature and remedial measures, IMY issued a reprimand.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: Cross-border complaint from Norway about Nordax Bank’s handling of data subject rights for direct marketing. IMY found violations of Articles 12(3), 12(6), 15, and 17 for failing to provide access/erasure and accurate, timely information on objection handling. IMY issued a reprimand and compliance orders to provide access, assess erasure, and inform the complainant, noting minor infringement and remedial steps taken.

IMY found that Coop’s use of Google Analytics transferred personal data to the US without ensuring an equivalent level of protection, violating Article 44. SCCs and Google’s/Coop’s supplementary measures (including server-side container and IP anonymization) were deemed ineffective given US surveillance laws. IMY ordered compliance within one month and refrained from imposing a fine due to mitigating efforts.

IMY found that Dagens Industri’s use of Google Analytics transferred personal data to the US, violating Article 44 due to unmet Chapter V conditions. SCCs and additional contractual, organizational, and technical measures were deemed insufficient to prevent access by US authorities. IMY ordered compliance (cease the GA version used unless sufficient safeguards) and, considering mitigating factors, imposed no fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 61, Description: Telecommunications, Level: 2
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that Tele2’s use of Google Analytics on tele2.se transferred personal data to the US without meeting Chapter V GDPR conditions, violating Article 44 between 14 August 2020 and May 2023. SCCs and additional measures (including IP truncation) were deemed ineffective against potential access by US intelligence under FISA 702. IMY, acting as lead authority following an Austrian complaint, imposed a SEK 12 million fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4791, Description: Retail sale via mail order houses or via Internet, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that CDON’s use of Google Analytics on cdon.fi transferred personal data to the US without adequate safeguards, breaching GDPR Art. 44. SCCs and measures like IP truncation and Google’s protections were deemed insufficient given US surveillance laws. IMY ordered compliance with Chapter V (including ceasing the GA version used on 14-08-2020 absent sufficient safeguards) and imposed a SEK 300,000 fine.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6512, Description: Non-life insurance, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined Trygg-Hansa SEK 35 million for failing to implement appropriate technical measures, enabling unauthorized access via modifiable URLs to documents concerning about 650,000 customers, including health data, from October 2018 to February 2021. It found violations of Art. 5(1)(f) and Art. 32(1), assessed severity, duration, and group turnover, and referenced EDPB fining guidelines. Logs indicated 202 likely directly affected; post-incident measures did not mitigate the sanction.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4791, Description: Retail sale via mail order houses or via Internet, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint from Germany, found Trionic Sverige AB unlawfully disclosed the complainant’s data to an incorrect email (no necessity under Art. 6(1)) and provided insufficiently specific recipient information (Art. 13(1)(e)). IMY accepted legitimate interest for anti-fraud disclosure and for storing the IP address prior to cancellation, noted limited scope (one person) and improvements made, and issued a reprimand. No fine was imposed.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6619, Description: Other activities auxiliary to financial service activities, except insurance and pension funding, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined Indecap AB after an employee mistakenly emailed an unencrypted Excel file containing personal and financial data of about 52,000 customers to up to 2,813 unintended recipients. IMY found inadequate technical and organizational measures under Article 32(1), noting high risk due to the sensitivity and volume of data and deviations from control routines during the pandemic without compensatory measures. Mitigating factors included steps to replace email distribution, prompt notification to data subjects, and contacting recipients to delete the email.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6512, Description: Non-life insurance, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that If Skadeförsäkring AB sent an email with sensitive health data using only enforced TLS, which did not protect the content end-to-end. It held this failed to ensure appropriate security under Article 32(1) given the risk of unauthorized access after delivery to the recipient’s mail server. Considering it was a single incident and subsequent security improvements, IMY issued a reprimand under Article 58(2)(b).

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4791, Description: Retail sale via mail order houses or via Internet, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint originating in Norway, found that Ellos Group AB violated Article 32(1) by designing a “merge customer” process that allowed unauthorized access to a customer’s purchase and return history using publicly available data. The infringement was negligent, involved one data subject, no sensitive data, and Ellos implemented remedial measures during the investigation. IMY issued a reprimand, considering the minor nature of the infringement and absence of prior violations.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined Avanza Bank AB 15,000,000 SEK for violating GDPR Art. 5(1)(f) and Art. 32(1) after Meta Pixel’s AAM and AH features were inadvertently activated, causing unauthorized transfers of customers’ social security numbers and financial data to Meta from 2019-11-15 to 2021-06-02. IMY found the bank’s technical and organizational measures insufficient given bank secrecy and the high-risk nature of the processing affecting approximately 500,001–1,000,000 individuals. The bank disabled the pixel, confirmed deletion at Meta, and introduced stronger controls, but these did not mitigate the fine.

A11_DefendantName: Hospital Board in the Uppsala Region
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined the Hospital Board in the Uppsala Region SEK 1.6 million for sending unencrypted emails with sensitive health data to third countries and storing such data in Outlook between 25 May 2018 and 7 May 2019. IMY found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32(1) due to inadequate technical and organizational measures and non-compliance with regional guidelines. Mitigating weight was given to the later introduction of an encryption solution in September 2019.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 2910, Description: Manufacture of motor vehicles, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint, assessed Volvo Personvagnar AB’s handling of an Article 15 access request for vehicle service and warranty data. IMY found a breach of Article 12(3) because the full copy was provided only on 15 September 2021 after a 25 February 2020 request, and issued a reprimand. It considered the infringement minor, affecting one data subject, and noted the company had reviewed procedures.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint, found that Klarna Bank AB failed to provide information on the actual recipients of the complainant’s personal data, breaching Article 15 GDPR. IMY interpreted Article 15(1)(c) in light of Article 19 and the principles of fairness and transparency, noting that actual recipients should be provided when explicitly requested unless impossible or disproportionate. Given the minor nature of the infringement affecting one person and no sensitive data, IMY issued a reprimand.

An informational leaflet explains publication and anonymisation practices for Article 60 one-stop-shop decisions across various SAs, highlighting national restrictions and differences. It states that summaries are prepared by the EDPB Secretariat for information only and that only national decisions in the SA’s language are authentic. It lists SAs where decisions or summaries exclude personal or legal persons’ data and notes that HR summaries are not anonymised.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border complaint, investigated Klarna Bank AB’s handling of a data subject’s erasure request. It found a breach of Article 12(3) due to undue delay and failure to timely inform about an extension, noting the delay was largely due to individual human error affecting only one person. IMY issued a reprimand considering the infringement minor.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6312, Description: Web portals, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY examined a complaint about Google’s refusal to de-index Lexbase-related URLs and found a breach of Article 12(2) for not facilitating the data subject’s rights by shifting the burden and implying payment was needed to exercise them. IMY held there were no demonstrated overriding legitimate grounds (the complainant was not a public figure) and Google later removed the URLs and updated practices. Given remedial steps and difficult balancing, IMY issued a reprimand without a fine.

A11_DefendantName: The Health and Medical Services Board in Region Dalarna
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 86, Description: Human health activities, Level: 2
A50_CaseSummary: IMY fined the Health and Medical Services Board in Region Dalarna for sending appointment letters in window envelopes that revealed clinic information, disclosing sensitive health data and sometimes children’s data. It found a violation of Article 32 due to inadequate security measures over 6 May 2021 to 6 July 2022, affecting around 2,500 mailings per year. While noting some mitigating factors (physical mail and some steps taken), IMY imposed a SEK 200,000 administrative fine.

IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border case from Finland and Denmark, examined Lensway’s handling of two erasure requests from 2020. It found Lensway unlawfully demanded copies of ID and signatures and required submission by postal mail, breaching Articles 12(6) and 12(2) GDPR. IMY issued a reprimand, noting subsequent improvements and the limited scope involving two data subjects.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8020, Description: Security systems service activities, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY investigated Verisure after media reports alleging improper sharing of home camera footage; it found no evidence of that sharing but identified a breach of Art. 32(1) due to only 100-day retention of log data, hindering oversight. Verisure extended log retention to five years in August 2022, and IMY issued a reprimand for the period 20 April 2022 to August 2022. The processing posed high privacy risks given in-home cameras and a large customer base.

IMY found that Verifiera AB unlawfully processed sensitive health data by publishing searchable decisions in compulsory psychiatric care (LPT) and LVM cases, not covered by journalistic exceptions despite a publication certificate. IMY held that Article 9 GDPR was violated between 6 April and 28 June 2022 and that Article 9(2) exceptions (including consent and important public interest) did not apply. IMY issued a reprimand and ordered the company to prevent searches by name, personal identity number, or address to access such decisions within eight weeks.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4772, Description: Retail sale of pharmaceutical and medical goods, cosmetic and toilet articles in specialized stores, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY found that Apoteket AB violated Article 32(1) by failing to implement appropriate security when using Meta Pixel’s AAM, leading to transfers of purchase and contact data that could reveal health and sexual life information. The processing affected a large number of individuals over 19 Jan 2020–25 Apr 2022, posed high risk, and reflected inadequate organizational controls despite existing procedures. Assessing severity as low but requiring deterrence, IMY imposed a SEK 37,000,000 fine after considering Article 83 factors and turnover.

A14_EconomicSector: Code: 5820, Description: Software publishing, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY, acting as lead authority in a cross-border case, investigated MAG Interactive AB’s handling of a data subject’s erasure request for the QuizDuel game. IMY found violations of Article 12(6) for demanding unnecessary identity information and Article 12(2) for requiring the request to be submitted from within the game, and issued a reprimand. The account was deleted in November 2022, and remediation and the time elapsed led to a reprimand instead of a fine.

A11_DefendantName: Nordea Bank Abp, branch in Sweden
A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
A50_CaseSummary: IMY investigated a complaint under Article 15 GDPR about access to a recorded phone call with Nordea Bank Abp, branch in Sweden. Nordea enabled on-site listening, offered a transcript, and provided an audio copy containing the complainant’s voice while editing out the employee’s voice to protect the employee’s rights. IMY concluded the access request was satisfied and closed the case without further action.
